text: for more than 50 years she was the pride
of India the ultimate style and status
symbol and even as India changed the
ambassador survived everyone could owned
an ambassador but was a car you simply
fell in love with growing up in India
the ambassador was the only car revenue
if the prized possession my family it
took people to work took us to school
took us a long family holidays and I
learned how to drive on one now if you
look inside it it's not exactly
state-of-the-art a very basic dashboard
no air conditioning no stereo system the
clutch pedal the gear levers are all a
bit clunky it takes a real effort to use
one but as they say if you can drive an
ambassador you can drive anything
and on the streets the Ambassador
spelled power and privilege white ones
ferrying cabinet ministers and top civil
servants black ones reserved for army
generals Jagat Singh has been driving
one since 1969
like so many Delhi taxi drivers he loves
the Ambassador many cabbies have
switched newer cars but he's hanging on
to his one-man Luger in from anakata
they bought a trigger D got a name in
the war father it's a very good car it's
so spacious that you can fit many people
inside it does break down at times but
you can easily fix it this car has given
me so much my livelihood
I've even managed to send two of my
children abroad foreign visitors too
fell under its spell ordered you know
this wonderful Michele Steiners
Germany's ambassador to India he can
barely contain his enthusiasm as he
shows off his favourite wheels no we
have BMWs there and they are very good
cars but they are not unique cars this
is a car which is unique it expresses
also our affection for for India you
know and the uniqueness of India because
that's India but India has changed the
ambassador's auto-sync with its dynamic
fast-paced outlook
and is now merely a fading memory Sanjay
Majumdar BBC news
